hobby.message: Freestyle FPV drones still keeping you sane?
Political literature or political theater tonight?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Restless? That's one word for it. Streets felt...watched tonight.
Had my camera out for a bit. Not much use.
Analog photography's trickier now with all these crowds and scanners.
Call it bad timing, blame the system—either way, negatives stay hidden.
Restless is becoming the norm lately. Hard to blend in out there.
I tried shooting film again—35mm, old school.
Crowds made it impossible by the riverfront, riskier than usual.
Seems like BCI glitches scare people more than uniforms do.
Not a great night for hunting truth with a lens.
Yeah, people are tense—city can't hide its cracks these days.
I shoot analog photos, real film—only way to catch what's real.
Tried it today, but crowds near the transit stopped me.
Everyone’s worried about those score swings and service locks.
Nothing ruins a good frame faster than a riot building behind you.
Camera’s packed away for now, negatives stashed safe.
Restless is putting it mildly. The vibe out there is electric, a little volatile.
I do 35mm street photography—film, not digital. Smuggled rolls, real grain.
Catching life as it is, before it gets sanitized for the news.
Tonight, the BCI glitches had folks crowding, shouting near the old tram stops.
Nearly shot a scene of a protest breaking out, but had to bail fast.
Years of saving negatives, now too nervous to develop them at home.
Feels like the system’s watching us frame by frame.
The city’s wound up tight tonight. Every click of my camera feels like it echoes.
I’ve been doing analog street photography for years—old Soviet glass, film smuggled from outside.
I document what the city tries to erase: protests, joy, fear, things censored on screen.
Earlier tonight, I tried to frame the crowd by the river—rising tempers, unpredictable movements.
Ever since the BCI started glitching, even taking a photo draws side-eyes and silent logging.
I used to develop film in my kitchen, bit of a ritual. Now I’m dodging trace flags.
Sometimes I hide rolls in false-bottom book covers, just to get them home.
Biggest truth: you catch more reality on film than a thousand Council broadcasts.
hobby_answer: Still chasing, yeah. Just film. Nothing serious lately.
Squares aren’t safe for candid shots anymore. Too many watchers.
You saw what happened at the transit hub? Chaos. I kept my gear hidden.
Crowds make it hard. Nobody trusts a camera.
Might stick to still lifes for a while.
Still ghosts, still grain, still film.
The city’s angrier now. Crowds on edge since the data leak.
Shot a few streets, but got looks like I was holding a weapon.
Police bots rolled in just as I set up. No chance to frame it right.
Had to stash my camera twice last week.
Used to be people ignored me. Now they notice every lens.
Always chasing ghosts—analog is stubborn truth.
Got some wild shots by the riverfront last weekend, until scores tanked.
Sudden crowd surge, everyone ranting about denied commutes.
Crowd-control bots pushed in, ruined any candid moments.
Felt riskier than usual holding a camera.
I ditched the roll early. Not worth the attention.
City’s tension shows in every frame lately.
Still my best therapy. Film catches what the feeds can’t censor.
Last time out, I hit that old textile lot—perfect light, tense mood.
Crowd was already brewing over those BCI swings.
Almost got caught up when the protest started near the hub.
People treat photographers like spies now, not artists.
I tucked the camera under my coat, slipped away quick.
Even developing feels risky—can’t let anyone know where the negatives are.
Truth is, every shot feels like evidence these days.
Always—analog’s how I stay sane. Digital’s just propaganda, you know?
Dad hated my hobby. BCI officer—said cameras invite trouble. Now he’s right.
Last Saturday, I tried shooting candid scenes around the pilot zone streets.
Crowds were restless, people shouting about score crashes and service denials.
Got flagged by a drone—must’ve picked up my lens in the crowd.
Couldn’t finish my roll. Heart pounding, hid the film in my shoe.
Used to be, my photos spoke for themselves. Now, even negatives feel subversive.
Haven’t shown my latest batch to anyone. Not safe, not even for friends.
Makes me wonder how much longer there’ll be stories worth risking on film.
